CJT000002_rubric_category_0.ti: A. Identify the research method used in the study.

o.d: Does not accurately identify the research method used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.

  • The response includes no identification of the research method used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The study is an experiment.”

  • “The study is an observational study.”

o.d: Accurately identifies the research method used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately identifies the research method used in the study as a meta-analysis.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study is a meta-analysis.”

CJT000002_rubric_category_1.ti: B. State the operational definition of the type of pain that is treated with group therapy.

o.d: Does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response states a definition of the identified variable in the study that is not measurable or quantifiable.

  • The response does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The type of pain treated by group therapy was pain intensity.”

o.d: States a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response states that the operational definition of the type of pain treated with group therapy is any of these conditions: fibromyalgia, chronic pain, and/or specific pain.

  • The response states that the operational definition of the type of pain treated with group therapy is fibromyalgia or other, nonspecific musculoskeletal pain, chronic back pain, arthritis, combined back and neck pain, cancer-related pain, and headaches/migraines.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The type of pain treated by group therapy was fibromyalgia.”

  • “The researchers only used studies that treated fibromyalgia, specific pain, and/or chronic pain.”

  • “The operational definition of the type of pain was fibromyalgia, nonspecific musculoskeletal pain, chronic back pain, arthritis, combined back and neck pain, cancer-related pain, and headaches/migraines.”

CJT000002_rubric_category_2.ti: C. Describe what the small effect size indicates.

o.d: Does not accurately describe the identified statistic in relation to the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response restates the identified statistic without directly relating it to the study.

  • The response does not accurately describe what is meant by the identified statistic in relation to the study.

  • The response provides a definition of the identified statistic but does not accurately describe its meaning in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The effect size is large.”

  • “The effect size is where they measure the effect of the study.”

o.d: Accurately describes the identified statistic in relation to the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately describes the meaning of the effect size statistic as the difference in means across the studies is not large.

  • The variables in the studies from the meta-analysis both need to be represented in the answer.

  • The response cannot parrot the question (meaning it cannot use the word “small” to describe the effect size).

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The impact of the group therapy on pain perception was weak or small.”

  • “The difference in the means between the group that received group therapy and waitlist group is not large.”

CJT000002_rubric_category_3.ti: D. Identify one ethical guideline described in the study. Describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.

o.d:
Does not accurately identify one ethical guideline described in the study

AND/OR

Does not correctly describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not identify and/or describe an ethical guideline applied by researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline that researchers should have applied but was not mentioned in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline not applied by the researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes other features of the study that are not ethical guidelines.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “It’s important for researchers to ensure participants are treated ethically.” [No ethical guideline identified or described]

  • “The researchers should have kept the participant information confidential.” [Identifies an ethical guideline not described in the study]

  • “The study was approved by an IRB and the researchers debriefed their participants after the study.” [Identifies an ethical guideline described in the study, but no description of how guideline was applied in the study.]

  • “The researchers used surveys that were administered in a standardized way.” [Identifies and describes a feature of the study that is not an ethical guideline]

o.d:
Accurately identifies one ethical guideline described in the study

AND

Accurately describes one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response identifies institutional review and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when a group of professionals reviewed the study plan to determine the appropriateness of the study.

    OR

  • The response identifies informed consent and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.

    OR

  • The response identifies anonymity and describes that the researchers maintained the data in a way that individual participant information would not be known.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study was approved by an Institutional Review Board, which is when professionals in the field to ensure ethics were followed."

    OR

  • “The study obtained informed consent which is when the participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.”

    OR

  • “Researchers maintained anonymity when they ensured that the individual participants would not be known.”

CJT000002_rubric_category_4.ti: E. Explain the extent to which the research findings may or may not be generalizable using specific and relevant evidence from the study.
CJT000002_rubric_category_4.s: If students assert the study is “partly” generalizable or asserts the study is both generalizable and not generalizable, their evidence must support their assertion by showing ways the study is generalizable and is not generalizable to earn one point.

o.d:
Does not propose a claim regarding the generalizability of the study to a population (general or specific).

OR

Does not use specific and relevant evidence that references participant variables which would impact the generalizability of the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response proposes no claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study.

  • The response proposes a claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study but makes no reference to a population (general or specific).

  • The response uses evidence that does not apply to the generalizability of the conclusion of the study (e.g., reliability, validity, sample size).

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The study is generalizable.”

  • “The study is generalizable to the larger population.”

  • “The study used males.” [Does not propose a claim about generalizability].

o.d: Explains the extent to which the study is generalizable using specific and relevant evidence referencing participant variables from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants) to explain the extent of the generalizability of the study.

  • The response proposes that the study is or is not generalizable to the population relevant to the study because of specific and relevant evidence derived from the participant information from the study.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study is not generalizable globally because they only used research that was conducted in English-speaking nations.”

  • “The study is only generalizable to people who have the types of pain conditions listed in the research.”

CJT000002_rubric_category_5.ti: F. Explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the idea that a combination of medication and psychological therapies is more effective than a single intervention for pain management.

o.d: Does not accurately explain how the results of the study support or refute the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the idea that a combination of medication and psychological therapies is more effective than a single intervention for pain management.

  • The response does not accurately explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the idea that a combination of medication and psychological therapies is more effective than a single intervention for pain management.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Taking psychoactive drugs for pain can be addicting.”

  • “This study shows that taking psychoactive drugs for pain might not be the only way to combat pain.”

o.d:
Uses the results of the study but does not explain how the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted.

OR

Explains that the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted but does not use any results from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes that the evidence alone is sufficient to demonstrate the application of the idea that a combination of medication and psychological therapies is more effective than a single intervention for pain management.

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to explain idea that a combination of medication and psychological therapies is more effective than a single intervention for pain management. However, the interpretation of the results of the study includes some inaccuracies.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Pain is not just a matter of intensity, but also beliefs about pain.” [Explanation without using results]

  • “The study shows that people’s perception of pain was improved through group therapy.” [Result from the study without further explanation]

o.d: Uses a specific result from the study to explain how the results support or refute the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question. The results are accurately interpreted.
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to accurately explain the idea that a combination of medication and psychological therapies is more effective than a single intervention for pain management. The results of the study are accurately interpreted.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “The research shows that group therapy can help with perception of pain, not just the physical sensation of pain.”

  • “The research shows how people attribute the cause or impact pain to themselves can influence how they perceive pain.”

  • “People may experience pain better because they have role models in their group therapy session that show them techniques for dealing with pain better.”

DPB000001_rubric_category_0.ti: A. Identify the research method used in the study.
DPB000001_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.

  • The response includes no identification of the research method used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The study is correlational.”

  • “The study is a survey.”

o.d: Accurately identifies the research method used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately identifies the research method used in the study as an experiment.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study is an experiment.”

DPB000001_rubric_category_1.ti: B. State the operational definition of PTSD symptom severity.
DPB000001_rubric_category_1.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response states a definition of the identified variable in the study that is not measurable or quantifiable.

  • The response does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “PTSD is caused by trauma people experience in life.”

  • “Depression is measured by the score on the depression inventory.”

o.d: States a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response states that the operational definition of PTSD symptom severity as the score from the structured interview and the PTSD symptom severity survey.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “PTSD symptom severity is operationally defined as the score from the structured interview and the PTSD symptom severity survey.”

DPB000001_rubric_category_2.ti: C. Describe what the difference in means indicates for the three groups’ scores on the anxiety inventory.
DPB000001_rubric_category_2.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately describe the identified statistic in relation to the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response restates statistic without directly relating it to the study.

  • The response does not accurately describe what is meant by the difference in means among the three groups for the anxiety inventory.

  • The response provides a definition of the statistic but does not accurately describe its meaning in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The means are 18.83, 13.28, and 17.17.”

  • “The means are different in that one is lower than the other two.”

  • “The means are the average of the responses to the survey.”

o.d: Accurately describes the identified statistic in relation to the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately describes the meaning of the difference in means among the three groups for the anxiety inventory in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The imaginal exposure group had the lowest mean as compared to the other two groups.”

  • “The virtual reality and waitlist group had higher means than the imaginal exposure group.”

DPB000001_rubric_category_3.ti: D. Identify one ethical guideline described in the study. Describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.
DPB000001_rubric_category_3.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not accurately identify one ethical guideline described in the study

AND/OR

Does not correctly describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not identify an ethical guideline applied by researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies an ethical guideline that researchers should have applied but was not mentioned in the study.

  • The response identifies an ethical guideline not applied by the researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies other features of the study that are not ethical guidelines.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The researchers prevented soldiers from engaging in therapy.”

  • “The researchers should have debriefed the participants after the study was concluded.”

  • “The researchers kept the participant information confidential.”

  • “The experimenters randomly assigned soldiers to condition.”

o.d:
Accurately identifies one ethical guideline described in the study

AND

Accurately describes one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response indicates that the experiment was approved by an Institutional Review Board.

  • The response indicates that participants gave informed consent.

  • The response indicates that the researchers did no harm to the participants in one of two ways: by following therapeutic practices or by providing therapy to the participants who were waitlisted after the study concluded.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • The research was approved by an Institutional Review Board.

  • Soldiers provided informed consent before they participated in the experiment.

  • Researchers ensured that they followed best practices for therapy with all the patients, meaning they did no harm.

  • Researchers made sure the waitlisted soldiers got therapy after the study was over, meaning they did no harm.

DPB000001_rubric_category_4.ti: E. Explain the extent to which the research findings may or may not be generalizable using specific and relevant evidence from the study.
DPB000001_rubric_category_4.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Note:

  • If students assert the study is “partly” generalizable or assert the study is both generalizable and not generalizable, their evidence must support their assertion by showing ways the study is both generalizable and not generalizable to earn 1 point.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not explain the extent to which the study is generalizable.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response proposes no claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study.

  • The response proposes a claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study but makes no reference to a population (general or specific).

  • The response uses evidence that does not apply to the generalizability of the conclusion of the study (e.g., reliability, validity, sample size).

  • The response only proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants).

  • The response only uses evidence about participant variables to imply generalizability. The response does not directly propose the extent of the generalizability of the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The study is generalizable.”

  • “The study is generalizable to the larger population.”

  • “The study used only men.” [Does not propose a claim about generalizability].

o.d: Explains the extent to which the study is generalizable using specific and relevant evidence referencing participant variables from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants) to explain the extent of the generalizability of the study.

  • The response proposes that the study is or is not generalizable to the population relevant to the study because of specific and relevant evidence derived from the participant information from the study.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The results may generalize to soldiers who have deployment-related traumas.”

  • “The results may not generalize well to the people who need treatment for other mental disorders, including schizophrenia because all the participants in this study only had PTSD.”

DPB000001_rubric_category_5.ti: F. Explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes that modeled refusal plays a role in obedience.
DPB000001_rubric_category_5.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately explain how the results of the study support or refute the psychological concept presented in the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the hypothesis related to treatment effectiveness.

  • The response does not accurately explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the hypothesis related to treatment effectiveness.

Examples that earn 0 points

  • “The researchers reported that therapy works.”

  • “Virtual reality exposure therapy was superior to other treatments in reducing anxiety.”

o.d:
Uses the results of the study but does not explain how the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted.

OR

Explains that the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted but does not use any results from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes that the evidence alone is sufficient to demonstrate the application of the hypothesis without additional explanation.

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to explain the hypothesis. However, the interpretation of the results of the study includes some inaccuracies.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • The virtual reality exposure therapy was not as effective because it would be like reliving the trauma, which could cause more damage. [Explanation without using results]

  • The imaginal exposure therapy was shown to be more effective than the virtual reality exposure therapy. [Result from the study without further explanation]

  • The virtual reality therapy was better than no therapy at all, which means it is most effective for treating this type of condition. [Evidence includes an inaccurate interpretation.]

o.d: Uses a specific result from the study to explain how the results support or refute the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question. The results are accurately interpreted.
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to accurately explain the hypothesis. The results of the study are accurately interpreted.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “The findings of the study refute the idea that virtual reality exposure therapy is most effective for treating PTSD because the imaginal therapy group had a lower mean difference on all four measures, showing that it was more effective.”

  • “The imaginal group had 50% of participants experience reliable and significant change, which means that the results show that virtual reality was not the most effective treatment for PTSD.”

DXP000001_rubric_category_0.ti: The following question has three parts: Part A, Part B, and Part C. Use the three sources provided to answer all parts of the question.  Using the sources provided, develop and justify an argument about a note-taking technique that is more likely to improve memory retrieval. A. Propose a specific and defensible claim based in psychological science that responds to the question.
DXP000001_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • A claim that meets the criteria can be awarded the points regardless of whether the responses in Parts B and C successfully support the claim.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not propose a claim that is relevant to the question
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response describes the question without making a claim.

  • The response proposes a claim unrelated to the question.

  • The response proposes an oversimplified conclusion or evidence from a provided source.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The amount of words in notes is not related to how well people do on a quiz.”

  • “Students should take good notes.”

  • “It doesn’t matter which method students use to take notes as long as they take notes.”

  • “Students should take more notes.”

  • “It doesn’t matter which method students use to take notes as long as they capture the main idea of the topic.”

o.d: Proposes a claim that is relevant to the question
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim that suggests a positive or negative effect on the question.

  • The response proposes a recommendation for the application of the question.

  • The response proposes a specific effect on the question.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Students should take notes by hand because it’s more likely to improve memory retrieval.”

  • “The research shows that factual memory is good when students take notes on a laptop so they should choose this method.”

  • “I believe that to improve memory for test material students should combine techniques and use both a computer to take notes and handwritten notes.”

DXP000001_rubric_category_1.ti: B. (i) Support your claim using at least one piece of specific and relevant evidence from one of the sources.
DXP000001_rubric_category_1.s:
For Part B and Part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1,...”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn this point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. Since citing specific numbers is not required to score the point, slight errors in reporting specific data can still earn the point when the direction of the difference or relationship of the data cited is correct.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not identify nor correctly cite one piece of specific evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim. Any evidence provided is not relevant to the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response identifies no evidence.

  • The evidence is not correctly cited.

  • The evidence is nonspecific.

  • The response provides evidence not relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Evidence shows that taking notes verbatim is more important than summarizing.”

  • “Notetaking is important to learning.”

o.d: Uses one piece of correctly cited, specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The evidence is correctly cited and provides specific and accurate evidence relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “According to Source 1, students who take notes by hand do better on concept application questions than students who take notes on a laptop.”

  • “Source 2 says that students who take notes on a computer are going to take more notes than students who take notes by hand.”

DXP000001_rubric_category_2.ti: B. (ii) Explain how the evidence from Part B (i) supports your claim using a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology.
DXP000001_rubric_category_2.s:
For Part B and Part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1,...”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in B (i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The use of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) is preferred but not required. The application of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding.

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be evidence. All text before the citation will be considered evidence. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.

  • Concepts used in the sources that are not eligible to be used for the application point are "memory," "recall," "distractor task," "factual-recall," "conceptual-application," "chunks," "informed consent," "randomly assigned," "mean," "statistically significant," "standard deviation," "replication," "cognitive," "retention," "efficacy," "median," and "sample size."

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not explain the relationship between the evidence and the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately interpret the evidence.

  • The response identifies evidence without explanation of how it relates to the claim.

  • The response provides opinions with no reference to the sources provided.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The evidence proves my claim.”

  • “The evidence says that notetaking by computer is less effective than notetaking by hand.”

o.d: Explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence in supporting the claim, but does not apply a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “If students take notes by hand, they will put the notes into their own words, which is better because they remember more.”

  • “Students who take more notes will have more content to study, which increases their chances of getting right answers on a quiz.”

o.d: Applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding to explain how the evidence supports the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence and applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding correctly.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “Students taking notes by hand will be more likely to engage in semantic encoding because they will have to process the meaning of the notes they are taking.”

  • “Students who take notes on a laptop are more likely to be distracted, which means they could miss details in the environment, which is known as inattentional blindness.”

DXP000001_rubric_category_3.ti: C. (i)  Support your claim using an additional piece of specific accurate, and relevant evidence from a different source than the one that was used in Part B (i).
DXP000001_rubric_category_3.s:
For Part B and Part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1,...”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn this point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. Since citing specific numbers is not required to score the point, slight errors in reporting specific data can still earn the point when the direction of the difference or relationship of the data cited is correct.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not identify nor correctly cite a different piece of specific evidence from either of the other two provided sources to support the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response identifies no evidence.

  • The evidence is not correctly cited.

  • The evidence is nonspecific.

  • The evidence is from the same source as the one used in Part B.

  • The response provides evidence not relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “One study did not find a difference in the method of notetaking quiz performance.”

  • “The study found that the evidence proves that notetaking is important for learning.”

o.d: Uses a different piece of correctly cited, specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from either of the other two provided sources to support the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The evidence is correctly cited and provides a different piece of specific and accurate evidence relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “One study (Source 2) did not find a difference in the method of notetaking on quiz performance on conceptually based questions.”

  • “In Source 3 it says that there was no significant difference in test performance between notes taken on tablets, laptops, or handwritten.”

DXP000001_rubric_category_4.ti: C. (ii) Explain how the evidence from Part C (i) supports your claim using a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology than the one that was used in Part B (ii).
DXP000001_rubric_category_4.s:
For Part B and Part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1,...”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in C (i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The explanation and application points can be earned if the response uses the same source in both Parts B and C, provided that the evidence used in Part B and Part C is different.

  • The use of a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) is preferred but not required. The application of a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding.

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be evidence. All text prior to the citation will be considered evidence. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.
