  • “Researchers obtained informed consent.”

  • “Researchers obtained informed assent.”

IJC000001_rubric_category_4.ti: E. Explain the extent to which the research findings may or may not be generalizable using specific and relevant evidence from the study.
IJC000001_rubric_category_4.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Note:

  • If students assert the study is “partly” generalizable or assert the study is both generalizable and not generalizable, their evidence must support their assertion by showing ways the study is both generalizable and not generalizable to earn 1 point.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not explain the extent to which the study is generalizable.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response proposes no claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study.

  • The response proposes a claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study but makes no reference to a population (general or specific).

  • The response uses evidence that does not apply to the generalizability of the conclusion of the study (e.g., reliability, validity, sample size).

  • The response only proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants).

  • The response only uses evidence about participant variables to imply generalizability. The response does not directly propose the extent of the generalizability of the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The study is generalizable.”

  • “The study is generalizable to the larger population.”

  • “The study used only men.” [Does not propose a claim about generalizability].

o.d: Explains the extent to which the study is generalizable using specific and relevant evidence referencing participant variables from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants) to explain the extent of the generalizability of the study.

  • The response proposes that the study is or is not generalizable to the population relevant to the study because of specific and relevant evidence derived from the participant information from the study.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The participants were drawn from eight counties in the Midwest, so generalizability to other Americans may be limited.”

  • “The participants were all white, so we would need a more racially diverse sample to know how well the relationship between puberty and depression described in this study applies to other groups.”

IJC000001_rubric_category_5.ti: F. Explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the idea that it is more advantageous if puberty is started earlier rather than later.
IJC000001_rubric_category_5.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately explain how the results of the study support or refute the psychological concept presented in the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the hypothesis related to treatment effectiveness.

  • The response does not accurately explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the hypothesis related to treatment effectiveness.

Examples that earn 0 points

  • “They found a gender difference in depressive symptoms.”

  • “The researchers were surprised that boys reported more depressive symptoms than did girls.”

o.d:
Uses the results of the study but does not explain how the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted.

OR

Explains that the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted but does not use any results from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes that the evidence alone is sufficient to demonstrate the application of the hypothesis without additional explanation.

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to explain the hypothesis. However, the interpretation of the results of the study includes some inaccuracies.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “It is more advantageous for girls to have puberty early because they will be more popular with their social group.” [Explanation without using results]

  • “Girls who develop early are more likely to be depressed in high school.” [Result from the study without further explanation]

  • “It is more advantageous for people to develop early because there was no difference in depressive symptoms between on-time and late developers.” [Evidence includes an inaccurate interpretation.]

o.d: Uses a specific result from the study to explain how the results support or refute the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question. The results are accurately interpreted.
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to accurately explain the hypothesis. The results of the study are accurately interpreted.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “The researchers discovered mixed support for their hypothesis. They found that girls who experienced puberty early reported greater depressive symptoms later when compared with girls who developed on-time or late. Inconsistent with their hypothesis, though, depression levels did not vary across pubertal status for boys.”

  • “It is better for boys to develop early than girls because girls had higher incidences of depression when they developed early.”

  • “It is better for girls to develop because girls who develop on time or late have lower risk of depression in high school.”

IQRprt1_rubric_category_0.ti: Using the sources provided, develop and justify an argument about the best time for school to start for secondary school students in grades 6 to 12. A.	Propose a specific and defensible claim based in psychological science that responds to the question.
IQRprt1_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • A claim that meets the criteria can be awarded the points regardless of whether the responses in Parts B and C successfully support the claim.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not propose a claim that is relevant to the question

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response describes the question without making a claim.

  • The response proposes a claim unrelated to the question.

  • The response proposes an oversimplified conclusion or evidence from a provided source.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “Determining a school start time for secondary students is difficult.”

  • “Sleep is important for teenagers.”

  • “Students should get more sleep.”

Proposes a claim that is relevant to the question

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim that suggests a positive or negative effect on the question.

  • The response proposes a recommendation for the application of the question.

  • The response proposes a specific effect on the question.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “School for secondary students should start later in the day.”

  • “School for secondary students should start some time before 8:00 a.m.”

  • “Secondary school students should start school at 9 a.m.”

  • “Secondary school students should start school two hours later than elementary students.”

IQRprt2_rubric_category_0.ti: B (i) Support your claim using at least one piece of specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from one of the sources.
IQRprt2_rubric_category_0.s:
For part B and part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1,...”

  • Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn the point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. Since citing specific numbers is not required to score the point, slight errors in reporting specific data can still earn the point when the direction of the difference or relationship of the data cited is correct.

o.d:
Does not identify nor correctly cite one piece of specific evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim. Any evidence provided is not relevant to the question.

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response identifies no evidence.

  • The evidence is not correctly cited.

  • The evidence is nonspecific.

  • The response provides evidence not relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “Sources say secondary school start time should be 9:00 a.m.” [The response has not provided a citation.]

  • “Secondary school start time should be 9 a.m. because people say taking tests before 9 a.m. is very difficult for teenagers.” [Test-taking is not a variable discussed in any of the provided sources.]

Uses one piece of correctly cited, specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim.

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The evidence is correctly cited.

  • The response provides specific and accurate evidence relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “Secondary school start time should be 9:00 a.m. 28% of students reported falling asleep in school at least once a week (Source 1).”

IQRprt2_rubric_category_1.ti: B (ii) Explain how the evidence from part B (i) supports your claim using a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology.
IQRprt2_rubric_category_1.s:
• The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in B(i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The use of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2025) is preferred but not required. The application of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2025) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be “evidence”. All text before the citation will be considered evidence. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.

  • Concepts used in the sources that are not eligible to be used for the application point are “academic performance/achievement,” “sleep,” “mean,” “standard deviation,” “variable,” “statistically significant,” “sleep deprivation,” “convenience sample,” “survey,” “percentage,” “adolescents,” “quality of life,” “physical/mental health,” “sleep-wake cycle,” “anxiety disorders,” “mood disorders,” “stimulants,” “caffeine,” and “chronic sleepiness.”

o.d:
Does not explain the relationship between the evidence and the claim.

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately interpret the evidence.

  • The response identifies evidence without explanation of how it relates to the claim.

  • The response provides opinions with no reference to the sources provided.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “Secondary school start time should be 9:00 a.m. 28% of students reported falling asleep in school at least once a week.”

  • “Secondary school start time should be 9 a.m. because I believe this is the best for teenagers.”

Explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim.

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence in supporting the claim, but does not apply a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “This evidence supports the claim of starting school later (9 a.m. instead of 8 a.m.) because some high school students have to take care of their younger siblings after school.”

  • “This evidence supports the claim of starting school later (9 a.m. instead of 8 a.m.) because it will allow students to have one more hour of sleep.”

Applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding to explain how the evidence supports the claim.

Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence and applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding correctly.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “This evidence supports the claim of starting school later (9 a.m. instead of 8 a.m.) because it will allow students to have one more hour of sleep and potentially reduce the amount of time they fall asleep in school. When students have an adequate amount of sleep, their ability to consolidate and retrieve memory is better, thus positively affecting their learning.”

IQRprt3_rubric_category_0.ti: C (i) Support your claim using an additional piece of specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from a different source than the one that was used in part B (i).
IQRprt3_rubric_category_0.s:
For part B and part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1,...”

  • Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn the point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. Since citing specific numbers is not required to score the point, slight errors in reporting specific data can still earn the point when the direction of the difference or relationship of the data cited is correct.

o.d:
Does not identify nor correctly cite a different piece of specific evidence from either of the other two provided sources to support the claim

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response identifies no evidence.

  • The evidence is not correctly cited.

  • The evidence is nonspecific.

  • The evidence is from the same source as the one used in part B.

  • The response provides evidence not relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Sources say secondary school start time should be 9:00 a.m.” [The response has not provided a citation.]

  • “Secondary school start time should be 9 a.m. because people say taking tests before 9 a.m. is very difficult for teenagers.” [Test-taking is not a variable discussed in any of the provided sources.]

  • “According to Source 1, students should get an additional hour of sleep to avoid sleep debt.” [The response uses the same source as used in part B.]

Uses a different piece of correctly cited, specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from either of the other two provided sources to support the claim

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The evidence is correctly cited.

  • The response provides specific and accurate evidence relevant to the claim.

  • The evidence is from a different source than the one used in part B.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “According to Source 2, students earned higher GPAs when they started school one hour later.”

IQRprt3_rubric_category_1.ti: C (ii) Explain how the evidence from part C (i) supports your claim using a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology than the one that was used in part B (ii).
IQRprt3_rubric_category_1.s:
• The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in C(i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The explanation and application points can be earned if the response uses the same source in both parts B and C, provided that the evidence used in part B and part C is different.

  • The use of a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2025) is preferred but not required. The application of a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2025) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding.

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be “evidence”. All text prior to the citation will be considered “evidence”. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.

  • Concepts used in the sources that are not eligible to be used for the application point are “academic performance/achievement,” “sleep,” “mean,” “standard deviation,” “variable,” “statistically significant,” “sleep deprivation,” “convenience sample,” “survey,” “percentage,” “adolescents,” “quality of life,” “physical/mental health,” “sleep-wake cycle,” “anxiety disorders,” “mood disorders,” “stimulants,” “caffeine,” and “chronic sleepiness.”

o.d:
Does not explain the relationship between the evidence and the claim

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately interpret the evidence.

  • The response identifies evidence without explanation of how it relates to the claim.

  • The response provides opinions with no reference to the sources provided.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “Students should get more sleep because it is good for them.”

  • “The evidence clearly supports my claim.”

  • “This evidence supports my claim because getting an additional hour of sleep can improve memory consolidation.” [The response uses a concept from part B.]

Explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence, but does not apply a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding.

  • The response applies the same psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that was used in part B; however, the response explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim that does not rely on the application.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “This evidence supports my claim because getting an additional hour of sleep can improve academic performance, which is a benefit for students.”

Applies a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding to explain how the evidence supports the claim. The psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding is different from the one used in part B (ii).

Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence and applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is different from the one used in part B.

Examples that earn 2 points include the following:

  • “This evidence supports my claim because a student’s circadian rhythm would fall more naturally in the different start times.”

JQF000001_rubric_category_0.ti: A. Identify the research method used in the study.
JQF000001_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.

  • The response includes no identification of the research method used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The researcher used an experiment for this study.”

  • “The researcher used a survey.”

o.d: Accurately identifies the research method used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately identifies the research method used in the study as a correlational study.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The researchers used a correlational method.”

  • “The researchers used a correlational study.”

JQF000001_rubric_category_1.ti: B. State the operational definition of daily sleep duration.
JQF000001_rubric_category_1.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response states a definition of the identified variable in the study that is not measurable or quantifiable.

  • The response does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The operational definition is sleep duration.”

  • “They measured how much the students slept.”

o.d: States a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response states that the operational definition of daily sleep duration is the calculated difference between the times when the adolescent reported going to sleep and their waking time.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Daily sleep duration is measured by calculating the difference between the times when the student went to sleep and when the student woke up.”

JQF000001_rubric_category_2.ti: C. Describe the meaning of standard deviation of the parents’ age in the study.
JQF000001_rubric_category_2.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately describe the identified statistic in relation to the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response restates the standard deviation without directly relating it to the study.

  • The response does not accurately describe what is meant by the standard deviation in relation to the study.

  • The response provides a definition of the standard deviation but does not accurately describe its meaning in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The standard deviation of 5.4 for the study shows that the results are different from each other.”

  • “The standard deviation shows that the average age of parents is 47.”

  • “The mean age for the parents was 47.6 and the standard deviation was 5.4, this means that the age of any parent in the study could be up to 5.4 years above 47.6 or 5.4 years below 47.6.”

  • “The standard deviation demonstrates that the adolescents’ ages are more similar.” [The response makes no reference to the parents’ ages.]

o.d: Accurately describes the identified statistic in relation to the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately describes what is meant by the standard deviation in relation to the study (i.e., the parent's ages are more varied/spread out/dispersed in the data set).

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The standard deviation of 5.4 for the parents’ ages shows that the ages differed more than the adolescents’ ages.”

  • “The standard deviation shows the parents’ ages were more diverse.”

  • “The standard deviation means that 68% of the parents ages were either 5.4 years higher or lower than the average age of the parents.”

  • “The standard deviation of the parents’ ages indicates that there was a greater variability in that data set.”

JQF000001_rubric_category_3.ti: D. Identify one ethical guideline described in the study. Describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.
JQF000001_rubric_category_3.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not accurately identify one ethical guideline described in the study.

AND/OR

Does not correctly describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not identify and/or describe the ethical guideline applied by researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline that researchers should have applied but was not described in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline not identified in the question.

  • The response identifies and describes other features of the study that are not ethical guidelines.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “It’s important for researchers to ensure participants are treated ethically.” [No ethical guideline identified or described]

  • “The researchers should have kept the participant information anonymous.” [Identifies an ethical guideline not described in the study]

  • “The study was approved by an IRB and the researchers debriefed their participants after the study.” [Identifies an ethical guideline described in the study, but no description of how guideline was applied in the study.]

  • “The researchers used surveys that were administered in a standardized way.” [Identifies and describes a feature of the study that is not an ethical guideline]

o.d:
Accurately identifies one ethical guideline described in the study.

AND

Accurately describes one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response identifies institutional review and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when a group of professionals reviewed the study plan to determine the appropriateness of the study.

    OR

  • The response identifies informed consent and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.

    OR

  • The response identifies informed assent and describes that the participants who were underage agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study was approved by an Institutional Review Board, which is when professionals in the field to ensure ethics were followed."

    OR

  • “The study obtained informed consent which is when the participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.”

    OR

  • “The study obtained informed assent which is when the underage participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.”

JQF000001_rubric_category_4.ti: E. Explain the extent to which the research findings may or may not be generalizable using specific and relevant evidence from the study.
JQF000001_rubric_category_4.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Note:

  • If students assert the study is “partly” generalizable or assert the study is both generalizable and not generalizable, their evidence must support their assertion by showing ways the study is both generalizable and not generalizable to earn 1 point.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not explain the extent to which the study is generalizable.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response proposes no claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study.

  • The response proposes a claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study but makes no reference to a population (general or specific).

  • The response uses evidence that does not apply to the generalizability of the conclusion of the study (e.g., reliability, validity, sample size).

  • The response only proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants).

  • The response only uses evidence about participant variables to imply generalizability. The response does not directly propose the extent of the generalizability of the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “It all depends on the variables that are measured, like the chaos that might be happening in the house.”

  • “They used a sample size population of about 200 participants.”

  • “The study’s results show significance with p-values of less than .05.”

  • “The participants were randomly sampled.”

  • “They got people from different races, which makes it more reliable.”

  • “The study is generalizable.”

  • “The study is not generalizable.”

  • “The conclusions of the study are generalizable to adults.”

  • “The conclusions of the study are generalizable to adults because the sample size is large.”

  • “Of the adults researchers surveyed, 70% had attended 4 years of college.”

o.d: Explains the extent to which the study is generalizable using specific and relevant evidence referencing participant variables from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants) to explain the extent of the generalizability of the study.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study is not generalizable to the larger population because over 70% of the participants were educated with at least 4 years of college.”

  • “The researchers gathered participants who are of different races, gender, and education level meaning they covered a bigger part of the population, and the results can be used for the majority of people.”

JQF000001_rubric_category_5.ti: F. Explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the idea that the quality of sleep is more important than the duration of sleep.
JQF000001_rubric_category_5.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately explain how the results of the study support or refute the psychological concept presented in the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not explain how at least one of the research findings support or refute that sleep quality is more important than sleep duration.

  • The response does not accurately explain how at least one of the research findings support or refute that sleep quality is more important than sleep duration.

Examples that earn 0 points

  • “The study shows that sleep duration is important.”

  • “The study shows that sleep duration does not matter.”

o.d:
Uses the results of the study but does not explain how the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted.

OR

Explains that the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted but does not use any results from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes that the evidence alone is sufficient to demonstrate that sleep quality is more important than sleep duration without additional explanation.

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to explain how sleep quality is more important than sleep duration. However, the interpretation of the results of the study includes some inaccuracies.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Sleep quality is more important than sleep duration because it’s healthier for students.”

  • “The study showed that sleep duration did predict adolescent mood and anxiety disorders at a significant level.” [The response provides results of the study without an explanation.]

  • “Sleep quality is more important than sleep duration. When comparing the participants who had better sleep quality, they showed fewer signs of anxiety and depressive symptoms. However, the results for sleep duration did not help predict anxiety and depressive symptoms.” [The response provides evidence but includes an inaccurate interpretation.]

o.d: Uses a specific result from the study to explain how the results support or refute the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question. The results are accurately interpreted.
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to accurately explain how sleep quality is more important than sleep duration. The results of the study are accurately interpreted.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “The conclusions from the study support the idea that quality of sleep is more important than the duration of sleep because researchers found out that better sleep quality the previous night was associated with fewer anxiety and depressive symptoms reported that evening.”

MCDprt1_rubric_category_0.ti: A.	Identify the research method used in the study.
MCDprt1_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.

  • The response includes no identification of the research method used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The research is a correlational study.”

Accurately identifies the research method used in the study.

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately identifies the research method used in the study as an experiment.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The research method is an experiment.”

MCDprt2_rubric_category_0.ti: B.	State the operational definition of executive functioning.
MCDprt2_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable used in the study.

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response states a definition of the identified variable in the study that is not measurable or quantifiable.

  • The response does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Executive functioning is not helped by multivitamins.”

  • “Executive functioning is how many words they recall.”

States a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response states that the operational definition of executive functioning is whether the participant correctly identified the second set of items shown as being the same as or different from the first set of items more quickly.

  • The response states that the operational definition of executive functioning is the scores on the test.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The operational definition of ‘executive functioning’ is if the person was able to correctly and quickly identify the second set of items shown as being different from or the same as the first set of items.”

  • “The operational definition is the scores on the executive functioning test.”

MCDprt3_rubric_category_0.ti: C.	Describe the meaning of the differences in the means for the immediate recall task between the multivitamin group and the placebo group.
MCDprt3_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not accurately describe the identified statistic in relation to the study.

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response restates the differences in the means for the immediate recall task between the multivitamin group and the placebo group without directly relating it to the study.

  • The response does not accurately describe what is meant by the differences in the means for the immediate recall task between the multivitamin group and the placebo group in relation to the study.

  • The response provides a definition of the differences in the means for the immediate recall task between the multivitamin group and the placebo group but does not accurately describe its meaning in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The difference in the means says that they are different.” [The response does not describe what this difference means.]

  • “The mean for the multivitamin group in Year 3 is 1.1, and the mean for the placebo group was 0.9.” [The response does not describe what this difference means.]

  • “The mean is the average of a group of data.”

Accurately describes the identified statistic in relation to the study.

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately describes the meaning of the differences in the means for the immediate recall task between the multivitamin group and the placebo group in relation to the study.

  • The response accurately describes that the means show that the multivitamin group recalled more than the placebo group.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The means show that the multivitamin group had better recall than the placebo group.”

  • “The means show that the placebo group had worse recall than the multivitamin group.”

  • “The mean for the multivitamin group in Year 3 is 1.1, and the mean for the placebo group was 0.9. This means that the multivitamin group remembered more over time than the placebo group.”

MCDprt4_rubric_category_0.ti: D.	Identify one ethical guideline described in the study. Describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.
MCDprt4_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not accurately identify one ethical guideline described in the study

AND/OR

Does not correctly describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not identify and/or describe the ethical guideline applied by researchers in the study

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline that researchers should have applied but was not described in the study

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline not identified in the question.

  • The response identifies and describes other features of the study that are not ethical guidelines

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “It’s important for researchers to ensure participants are treated ethically.” [No ethical guideline identified or described.]

  • “The researchers should have kept the participant information anonymous.” [Identifies an ethical guideline not described in the study.]

  • “The study was approved by an IRB and the researchers debriefed their participants after the study.” [Identifies an ethical guideline described in the study, but no description of how guideline was applied in the study.]

  • “The researchers used surveys that were administered in a standardized way.” [Identifies and describes a feature of the study that is not an ethical guideline.

Accurately identifies one ethical guideline described in the study

AND

Accurately describes one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response identifies confidentiality and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when researchers ensured that the individual participants could not be identified from the data collected.

    OR

  • The response identifies informed consent and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.

    OR

  • The response identifies protection from harm and describes that the researchers considered/eliminated factors that might impose a burden/difficulty/stress for participants.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Researchers maintained confidentiality when they ensured that the individual participants could not be identified from the data collected.”

    OR

  • “The study obtained informed consent which is when the participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.”

    OR

  • “The researchers protected the participants from harm when they considered factors that might impose a difficulty for participants.”

MCDprt5_rubric_category_0.ti: E.	Explain the extent to which the research findings may or may not be generalizable using specific and relevant evidence from the study.
MCDprt5_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Note:

  • If students assert the study is “partly” generalizable or assert the study is both generalizable and not generalizable, their evidence must support their assertion by showing ways the study is both generalizable and not generalizable to earn 1 point.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not explain the extent to which the study is generalizable.

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response proposes no claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study.

  • The response proposes a claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study but makes no reference to a population (general or specific).

  • The response uses evidence that does not apply to the generalizability of the conclusion of the study (e.g., reliability, validity, sample size).

  • The response only proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants).

  • The response only uses evidence about participant variables to imply generalizability. The response does not directly propose the extent of the generalizability of the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The study is generalizable.”

  • “The study is generalizable to the larger population.”

  • “The study used both men and women.”

  • “The study is generalizable because everyone takes vitamins.”

Explains the extent to which the study is generalizable using specific and relevant evidence referencing participant variables from the study.

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants) to explain the extent of the generalizability of the study.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study is generalizable to both men and women because both were used in the study.”

  • “The study is generalizable to older adults only because that is the only group the researchers used.”

MCDprt6_rubric_category_0.ti: F.	Explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the researcher’s hypothesis that taking a multivitamin prevents cognitive decline in later life.
MCDprt6_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not accurately explain how the results of the study support or refute the psychological concept presented in the question.

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not explain how at least one of the research findings support or refute that taking a multivitamin prevents cognitive decline in later life.

  • The response does not accurately explain how at least one of the research findings support or refute that taking a multivitamin prevents cognitive decline in later life.

Examples that earn 0 points

  • “The study shows that executive functioning is not affected by taking a multivitamin, so it’s not worth it to take them.”

  • “The study shows that people should take a multivitamin.”

  • “Older adults should not take a multivitamin because of the side effects.”

Uses the results of the study but does not explain how the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted.

OR

Explains that the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted but does not use any results from the study.

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes that the evidence alone is sufficient to demonstrate that taking a multivitamin prevents cognitive decline in later life without additional explanation.

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to explain how taking a multivitamin prevents cognitive decline in later life. However, the interpretation of the results of the study includes some inaccuracies.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Older adults should take a multivitamin because it improves their memory and thinking.” [The response provides an explanation without using results.]

  • “Older adults gain 3.1 years of memory change because of taking a multivitamin.” [The response uses results from the study without further explanation.]

  • “Older adults should take a multivitamin because it improves their memory and executive functioning.” [The response uses evidence but includes an inaccurate interpretation.]

Uses a specific result from the study to explain how the results support or refute the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question. The results are accurately interpreted.

Responses that earn 2 points:

  • “This study shows that older adults can delay some cognitive decline if they take a multivitamin because it seems to improve episodic memory, but not executive functioning.”

  • “The study shows that taking a multivitamin does not totally prevent cognitive decline in later life because executive functioning is not significantly improved by taking one.”

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “This study shows that older adults can delay some cognitive decline if they take a multivitamin because it seems to improve episodic memory, but not executive functioning.”

  • “The study shows that taking a multivitamin does not totally prevent cognitive decline in later life because executive functioning is not significantly improved by taking one.”

VR838912_rubric_category_0.ti: A. Identify the research method used in the study.

o.d: Does not accurately identify the research method used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.

  • The response includes no identification of the research method used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • The research is an experiment.

  • The researchers used a semi-structured interview for this study. [The semi-structured interview is the measurement tool, not the research method.]

o.d: Accurately identifies the research method used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately identifies the research method used in the study as a case study.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • The research method used is a case study.

VR838912_rubric_category_1.ti: B. State the operational definition of addiction.

o.d: Does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response states a definition of addiction in the study that is not measurable or quantifiable.

  • The response does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of addiction as used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • Addiction is defined when you need to take a drug or else you’ll experience withdrawal.

  • Addiction is defined in this study is when the women were abusing drugs. [The response does not refer to how the researchers measured the variable.]

o.d: States a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response states the operational definition of addiction.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • The researchers operationally define “addiction” as the participants’ responses that refer to misusing substances in their lives.

  • The operational definition of addiction is when the participants described their substance use as “abusive.”

VR838912_rubric_category_2.ti: C. Describe the meaning of the percentages presented in the “hourly wage of those who are employed” category of demographic data.

o.d: Does not accurately describe the identified statistic in relation to the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response restates the percentages presented in the “hourly wage of those who are employed” category of demographic data without directly relating it to the study.

  • The response does not accurately describe what is meant by the percentages presented in the “hourly wage of those who are employed” category of demographic data in relation to the study.

  • The response provides a definition of the percentages presented in the “hourly wage of those who are employed” category of demographic data but does not accurately describe its meaning in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • The percentages show that one group is making more money than another. [The response is not specific to the demographics of the study.]

  • The percentages show that most women are making over $16 an hour. [The response does not accurately describe the statistic’s meaning.]

  • The percentages show the average of the data in the table. [The response provides a definition instead of an interpretation.]

o.d: Accurately describes the identified statistic in relation to the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately describes the meaning of the percentages presented in the “hourly wage of those who are employed” category of demographic data in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • The hourly wages percentages show that most of the women are making under $16 an hour.

  • The wages show that the majority of women are earning under $12.99 an hour.

VR838912_rubric_category_3.ti: D. Identify one ethical guideline described in the study. Describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.

o.d:
Does not accurately identify one ethical guideline described in the study

AND/OR

Does not correctly describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not identify and/or describe the ethical guideline applied by researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline that researchers should have applied but was not described in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline not identified in the question.

  • The response identifies and describes other features of the study that are not ethical guidelines.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “It’s important for researchers to ensure participants are treated ethically.” [No ethical guideline identified or described]

  • “The researchers should have kept the participant information anonymous.” [Identifies an ethical guideline not described in the study]

  • “The study was approved by an IRB and the researchers debriefed their participants after the study.” [Identifies an ethical guideline described in the study, but no description of how guideline was applied in the study.]

  • “The researchers used surveys that were administered in a standardized way.” [Identifies and describes a feature of the study that is not an ethical guideline]

o.d:
Accurately identifies one ethical guideline described in the study

AND

Accurately describes one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response identifies institutional review and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when a group of professionals reviewed the study plan to determine the appropriateness of the study.

    OR

  • The response identifies informed consent and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.

    OR

  • The response identifies confidentiality and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when researchers ensured that the individual participants could not be identified from the data collected.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “The study was approved by an Institutional Review Board, which is when professionals in the field to ensure ethics were followed."

    OR

  • “The study obtained informed consent which is when the participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.”

    OR

  • “Researchers maintained confidentiality when they ensured that the individual participants could not be identified from the data collected.”

VR840556_rubric_category_0.ti: A. Using the sources provided, develop and justify an argument about the impact of divided attention on performance of a task. Propose a specific and defensible claim based in psychological science that responds to the question.
VR840556_rubric_category_0.s: A claim that meets the criteria can be awarded the point regardless of whether the responses in Parts B and C successfully support the claim.

o.d: Does not propose a claim that is relevant to the question
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response describes the question without making a claim.

  • The response proposes a claim unrelated to the question.

  • The response proposes an oversimplified conclusion or evidence from a provided source.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “Divided attention is when you work on more than one thing at a time.”

  • “People shouldn’t be distracted.”

o.d: Proposes a claim that is relevant to the question
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a specific effect on the question.

  • The response proposes a claim that suggests a positive or negative effect on the question.

  • The response proposes a recommendation for the application of the question.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “When people divide their attention, by trying to do two things at once, it hurts their performance on a task.”

  • “Students should avoid trying to divide their attention at school because it negatively impacts their grades.”

VR840556_rubric_category_1.ti: B(i). Support your claim using at least one piece of specific and relevant evidence from one of the sources.
VR840556_rubric_category_1.s:
• Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn the point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. Since citing specific numbers is not required to score the point, slight errors in reporting specific data can still earn the point when the direction of the difference or relationship of the data cited is correct.

o.d: Does not identify nor correctly cite one piece of specific evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim. Any evidence provided is not relevant to the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response identifies no evidence.

  • The evidence is not correctly cited.

  • The evidence is nonspecific.

  • The response provides evidence not relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “Participants were 47 seconds slower in identifying the color of the word when they were doing two things at once.” [The response has not provided a citation.]

  • “Researchers found that divided attention is harmful.” [The evidence is nonspecific.]

o.d: Uses one piece of correctly cited, specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The evidence is correctly cited and provides specific and accurate evidence relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “According to Source 1, participants were 47 seconds slower in identifying the color of the word when they had to multitask.”

  • “Researchers have not found that multitasking negatively affects quiz performance on fact-based questions (Source 2).”

VR840556_rubric_category_2.ti: B(ii). Explain how the evidence from Part B (i) supports your claim using a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology.
VR840556_rubric_category_2.s:
• The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in B(i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The use of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) is preferred but not required. The application of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding.

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be “evidence”. All text before the citation will be considered evidence. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.

  • Concepts used in the sources that are not eligible to be used for the application point are “experiment,” “Stroop task,” “mean,” “interference,” “attitudes,” “survey,” “learning,” “multitasking,” “distractibility,” “concentrate/concentration,” “standard deviation,” “correlation (negative and positive),” “statistical significance,” “academic achievement,” “recall,” and “memory.”

o.d: Does not explain the relationship between the evidence and the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately interpret the evidence.

  • The response identifies evidence without explanation of how it relates to the claim.

  • The response provides opinions with no reference to the sources provided.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “This evidence proves that divided attention is beneficial.”

  • “This evidence supports my claim.”

o.d: Explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence in supporting the claim, but does not apply a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “This evidence shows that when students were interrupted with a text message while they were studying, they had a harder time recalling what they read, especially if they only reread the text.”

o.d: Applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding to explain how the evidence supports the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence and applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding correctly.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “People who divide their attention can experience inattentional blindness, meaning they miss important things in the environment because they aren’t paying proper attention making their performance on the task worse.”

VR840556_rubric_category_3.ti: C(i). Support your claim using an additional piece of specific and relevant evidence from a different source than the one that was used in Part B (i).
VR840556_rubric_category_3.s:
• Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn the point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. Since citing specific numbers is not required to score the point, slight errors in reporting specific data can still earn the point when the direction of the difference or relationship of the data cited is correct.

o.d: Does not identify nor correctly cite a different piece of specific evidence from either of the other two provided sources to support the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response identifies no evidence.

  • The evidence is not correctly cited.

  • The evidence is nonspecific.

  • The evidence is from the same source as the one used in Part B.

  • The response provides evidence not relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Participants were 47 seconds slower in identifying the color of the word when they had to multitask.” [The response has not provided a citation.]

  • “Researchers found that multitasking is harmful.” [The evidence in nonspecific.]

o.d: Uses a different piece of correctly cited, specific, and relevant evidence from either of the other two provided sources to support the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The evidence is correctly cited and provides specific and accurate evidence relevant to the claim.

  • The evidence is from a different source than the one used in Part B.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Source 2 showed that when students were distracted that did worse on the quiz.”

VR840556_rubric_category_4.ti: C(ii). Explain how the evidence from Part C (i) supports your claim using a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology than the one that was used in Part B (ii).
VR840556_rubric_category_4.s:
• The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in C(i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The explanation and application points can be earned if the response uses the same source in both Parts B and C, provided that the evidence used in Part B and Part C is different.

  • The use of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) is preferred but not required. The application of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding.

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be “evidence”. All text prior to the citation will be considered “evidence”. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.

  • Concepts used in the sources that are not eligible to be used for the application point are “experiment,” “Stroop task,” “mean,” “interference,” “attitudes,” “survey,” “learning,” “multitasking,” “distractibility,” “concentrate/concentration,” “standard deviation,” “correlation (negative and positive),” “statistical significance,” “academic achievement,” “recall,” and “memory.”

o.d: Does not explain the relationship between the evidence and the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately interpret the evidence.

  • The response identifies evidence without explanation of how it relates to the claim.

  • The response provides opinions with no reference to the sources provided.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “This evidence proves that dividing one’s attention is beneficial.”

  • “This evidence supports my claim.”

o.d: Explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence, but does not apply a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding.

  • The response applies the same psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that was used in Part B; however, the response explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim that does not rely on the application.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “This evidence shows that when students were interrupted with a text message while they were studying, they had a harder time recalling what they read, especially if they only reread the text.”

o.d: Applies a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding to explain how the evidence supports the claim. The psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding is different from the one used in Part B (ii).
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence and applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is different from the one used in Part B.

Examples that earn 2 points include the following:

  • “When someone is distracted by a text message, they really can’t encode the information they are reading into their memory and that’s why students did so poorly on their quiz.”

VR841036_rubric_category_0.ti: A. Using the sources provided, develop and justify an argument about the relationship between being in an ordered or cluttered environment and creativity. Propose a specific and defensible claim based in psychological science that responds to the question.
VR841036_rubric_category_0.s: A claim that meets the criteria can be awarded the point regardless of whether the responses in Parts B and C successfully support the claim.

o.d: Does not propose a claim that is relevant to the question
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response describes the question without making a claim.

  • The response proposes a claim unrelated to the question.

  • The response proposes an oversimplified conclusion or evidence from a provided source.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “You shouldn’t work in a disorderly room.”

  • “People do better in an orderly environment.”

o.d: Proposes a claim that is relevant to the question
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim that suggests a positive or negative effect on the question.

  • The response proposes a recommendation for the application of the question.

  • The response proposes a specific effect on the question.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “Working in a disorderly room leads people to be more creative.”

  • “Working in a tidy room leads a person to be less creative than someone working in a messy room.”

VR841036_rubric_category_1.ti: B(i). Support your claim using at least one piece of specific and relevant evidence from one of the sources.
VR841036_rubric_category_1.s:
• Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn the point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. Since citing specific numbers is not required to score the point, slight errors in reporting specific data can still earn the point when the direction of the difference or relationship of the data cited is correct.

o.d: Does not identify nor correctly cite one piece of specific evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim. Any evidence provided is not relevant to the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response identifies no evidence.

  • The evidence is not correctly cited.

  • The evidence is nonspecific.

  • The response provides evidence not relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “People in the messy room had more creative ideas than people in the orderly room.” [The response has not provided a citation.]

o.d: Uses one piece of correctly cited, specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The evidence is correctly cited and provides specific and accurate evidence relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “Source 1 showed that people in the messy room had more creative ideas than people in the orderly room.”

VR841036_rubric_category_2.ti: B(ii). Explain how the evidence from Part B (i) supports your claim using a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology.
VR841036_rubric_category_2.s:
• The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in B(i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The use of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) is preferred but not required. The application of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding.

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be “evidence”. All text before the citation will be considered evidence. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.

  • Concepts used in the sources that are not eligible to be used for the application point are “creativity,” “hypothesis,” “statistical significance,” “mean,” “cognitive processes,” “critical thinking,” “goal-directed behaviors,” “institutional review board,” “informed consent,” “random assignment,” “correlation,” “fluency,” “personality,” “self-control,” “trait,” and “survey.”

o.d: Does not explain the relationship between the evidence and the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately interpret the evidence.

  • The response identifies evidence without explanation of how it relates to the claim.

  • The response provides opinions with no reference to the sources provided.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • “It doesn’t seem to matter if you are in a cluttered or organized room on what you do.”

o.d: Explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence in supporting the claim, but does not apply a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • “Researchers showed that working in a disorderly room actually helps people generate more creative ideas.”

o.d: Applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding to explain how the evidence supports the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence and applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding correctly.

Examples that earn 2 points include the following:

  • “Researchers showed that working in a messy room helps people think in more divergent ways so that they can generate more ideas and be more creative.”

VR841036_rubric_category_3.ti: C(i). Support your claim using an additional piece of specific and relevant evidence from a different source than the one that was used in Part B (i).
VR841036_rubric_category_3.s:
• Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn the point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. VR841659_rubric_category_1.ti: B. Describe the meaning of the difference in the means for the percent correct for the spoken syllable identification task and the timbre identification task.

o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response restates the difference in the means for the percent correct for the spoken syllable identification task and the timbre identification task without directly relating it to the study.

  • The response does not accurately describe what is meant by the difference in the means for the percent correct for the spoken syllable identification task and the timbre identification task in relation to the study.

  • The response provides a definition of the difference in the means for the percent correct for the spoken syllable identification task and the timbre identification task but does not accurately describe its meaning in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 0 points include the following:

  • The difference in the means shows that one task is more than another. [The response is not specific to the study.]

  • The different means show that syllable identification is harder than timbre identification. [The response does not accurately describe the statistic’s meaning.]

  • The difference in means shows the difference in the average scores of each group. [The response provides a definition instead of an interpretation.]

o.d: Accurately describes the identified statistic in relation to the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately describes the meaning of the difference in the means for the percent correct for the spoken syllable identification task and the timbre identification task in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • The difference in means shows that the syllable identification task is easier to identify than the timbre identification task.

  • More participants identified the syllable identification task correct than they did for the timbre identification task.

Examples that earn 1 point include the following:

  • The study is not generalizable to a wide population of people.
