VR856497_rubric_category_4.ti: C. (ii) Explain how the evidence from part C (i) supports your claim using a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology than the one that was used in part B (ii).
VR856497_rubric_category_4.s:
For part B and part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1,...”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in C (i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The explanation and application points can be earned if the response uses the same source in both parts B and C, provided that the evidence used in part B and part C is different.

  • The use of a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2025) is preferred but not required. The application of a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2025) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding.

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be evidence. All text prior to the citation will be considered evidence. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.

  • Concepts used in the sources that are not eligible to be used for the application point are “attention,” “cognitive/cognitive development,” “motor skills,” “visual reception,” “comprehension,” “language/language development,” “correlation coefficient,” “mental imagery,” “working memory,” “survey,” “socio-emotional,” “behavioral,” “mean,” “standard deviation,” and “statistically significant.”

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not meet the criteria for one point.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately interpret the evidence.

  • The response identifies evidence without explanation of how it relates to the claim.

  • The response provides opinions with no reference to the sources provided.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Exposure to screen media is bad for children.”

  • “All the studies support the argument that cognitive development declines with screen media exposure.”

o.d: Explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence, but does not apply a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding.

  • The response applies the same psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that was used in part B; however, the response explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim that does not rely on the application.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “These studies support the claim that screen media exposure can impair cognitive development for children who are not engaged in learning activities when they are online.”

o.d: Applies a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding to explain how the evidence supports the claim. The psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding is different from the one used in part B (ii).
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence and applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is different from the one used in part B.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “These studies support the claim that screen media exposure can impair cognitive development because the brain becomes proficient in processing audio and visual information, and other forms of sensory processing may not be as strong.”

  • “The lower ability to use mental imagery to represent the external environment shows that young children may not have mastered the concrete operational stage of Piaget’s developmental theory.”

VR856535_rubric_category_0.ti: A. Identify the research method used in the study.
VR856535_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.

  • The response includes no identification of the research method used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The research is a correlational study.”

o.d: Accurately identifies the research method used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately identifies the research method used in the study as an experiment.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The research method is an experiment.”

VR856535_rubric_category_1.ti: B. State the operational definition of obedience.
VR856535_rubric_category_1.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response states a definition of the identified variable in the study that is not measurable or quantifiable.

  • The response does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The operational definition is whether the subject listened to the experimenter.”

o.d: States a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response states that the operational definition of obedience is the level of shock that the participant agrees to administer.

  • The response states that the operational definition of obedience is whether the participant continues administering shocks after 150-volts.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The operational definition of “obedience” is whether the person kept going after the 150-volt level.”

  • “The operational definition of obedience is what level of shock the participant goes to in the study.”

VR856535_rubric_category_2.ti: C. Describe the meaning of the standard deviation of 15.47 for the ages of the participants.
VR856535_rubric_category_2.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately describe the identified statistic in relation to the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response restates the identified statistic without directly relating it to the study.

  • The response does not accurately describe what is meant by the identified statistic in relation to the study.

  • The response provides a definition of the identified statistic but does not accurately describe its meaning in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The standard deviation is the difference between the oldest and youngest subject in the study.”

o.d: Accurately describes the identified statistic in relation to the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately describes that the standard deviation of 15.47 indicates that the ages of the participants differ from each other by an average of 15.47 years.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The standard deviation of 15.47 shows that the ages were spread out by about 15 years, on average.”

  • “The standard deviation shows that the age ranges were spread out pretty far from each other.”

VR856535_rubric_category_3.ti: D. Identify one ethical guideline described in the study. Describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.
VR856535_rubric_category_3.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d:
Does not accurately identify one ethical guideline described in the study

AND/OR

Does not correctly describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not identify and/or describe an ethical guideline applied by researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline that researchers should have applied but was not mentioned in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline not applied by the researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes other features of the study that are not ethical guidelines.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “It’s important for researchers to ensure participants are treated ethically.” [No ethical guideline identified or described]

  • “The researchers should have kept the participant information anonymous.” [Identifies an ethical guideline not described in the study]

  • “The study was approved by an IRB and the researchers debriefed their participants after the study.” [Identifies an ethical guideline described in the study, but no description of how guideline was applied in the study.]

  • “The researchers used surveys that were administered in a standardized way.” [Identifies and describes a feature of the study that is not an ethical guideline]

o.d:
Accurately identifies one ethical guideline described in the study

AND

Accurately describes one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response identifies institutional review and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when a group of professionals reviewed the study plan to determine the appropriateness of the study.

    OR

  • The response identifies informed consent and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.

    OR

  • The response identifies debriefing and describes that researchers informed participants of the true purpose of the study/method/variables after the study was complete.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study was approved by an Institutional Review Board, which is when professionals in the field to ensure ethics were followed."

    OR

  • “The study obtained informed consent which is when the participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.”

    OR

  • "The researchers debriefed participants by telling them what the real purpose of the study was when it was over.”

VR856535_rubric_category_4.ti: E. Explain the extent to which the research findings may or may not be generalizable using specific and relevant evidence from the study.
VR856535_rubric_category_4.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Note:

  • If students assert the study is “partly” generalizable or assert the study is both generalizable and not generalizable, their evidence must support their assertion by showing ways the study is both generalizable and not generalizable to earn 1 point.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not explain the extent to which the study is generalizable.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response proposes no claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study.

  • The response proposes a claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study but makes no reference to a population (general or specific).

  • The response uses evidence that does not apply to the generalizability of the conclusion of the study (e.g., reliability, validity, sample size).

  • The response only proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants).

  • The response only uses evidence about participant variables to imply generalizability. The response does not directly propose the extent of the generalizability of the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The study is generalizable.”

  • “The results are generalizable.”

  • “The study is generalizable to the larger population.”

  • “The study is not generalizable to lots of people.”

  • “The study used both men and women.”

o.d: Explains the extent to which the study is generalizable using specific and relevant evidence referencing participant variables from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants) to explain the extent of the generalizability of the study.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study is generalizable to the larger population.”

  • “The study is generalizable to both men and women because both were used in the study.”

  • “The study is generalizable to men and women between the ages of 20 to 81.”

  • “The study is not generalizable to nonbinary people because they only used men and women.”

  • “The study is not generalizable because the participants were not diverse enough.”

VR856535_rubric_category_5.ti: F. Explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes that modeled refusal plays a role in obedience.
VR856535_rubric_category_5.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not accurately explain how the results of the study support or refute the psychological concept presented in the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not explain how at least one of the research findings support or refute that modeled refusal plays a role in obedience.

  • The response does not accurately explain how at least one of the research findings support or refute that modeled refusal plays a role in obedience.

Examples that earn 0 points

  • “This study shows that people will not obey an authority figure.”

  • “This study shows that people should not obey authority figures.”

  • “A majority of the people in this study obeyed the authority figure.”

  • “Obeying an authority figure happens no matter if you are a man or a woman.”

o.d:
Uses the results of the study but does not explain how the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted.

OR

Explains that the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted but does not use any results from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes that the evidence alone is sufficient to demonstrate the application of that modeled refusal plays a role in obedience without additional explanation.

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to support or refute that modeled refusal plays a role in obedience. However, the interpretation of the results of the study includes some inaccuracies.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study showed that 36% of people refused to go on at some point before 150 volts.”

  • “The study showed that fewer people refused to go on as compared to Milgram’s original study.”

  • “The study shows that people will refuse to obey if someone models refusal.”

o.d: Uses a specific result from the study to explain how the results support or refute the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question. The results are accurately interpreted.
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to accurately explain how the results support or refute the idea that modeled refusal plays a role in obedience and the interpretation of the results of the study.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “The study showed that 36% of people stopped before 150 volts, showing that people seem to obey an authority figure less if there is someone modeling disobedience in the room.”

  • “This study supports the idea that that modeled refusal plays a role in obedience because the results from that condition showed that fewer people went beyond the 150-level shock than they did in Milgram’s study.”

WPO000003_rubric_category_0.ti: A. Identify the research method used in the study.

o.d: Does not accurately identify the research method used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately identify the research method used in the study.

  • The response includes no identification of the research method used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The study is correlation.”

  • “The study is an observational study.”

  • “The study measures learning.”

o.d: Accurately identifies the research method used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately identifies the research method used in the study as an experiment.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study is an experiment.”

WPO000003_rubric_category_1.ti: B. State the operational definition of the interruption in the teaching phase.

o.d: Does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response states a definition of the identified variable in the study that is not measurable or quantifiable.

  • The response does not state a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The interruption is a phone call.” [Not specific enough]

  • “The operational definition of the interruption is when the researchers disrupt the teaching of the word.”

o.d: States a measurable or quantifiable definition of the identified variable as used in the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response states that the operational definition of the interruption in the teaching session as a 30-second phone call from the researcher in which they had a friendly conversation.

  • The response must distinguish the interruption call from the transition, either by addressing the length of the call or the content of the call.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The interruption is defined as the 30-second phone call between the words the parent was teaching to the child”.

  • “The operational definition of the interruption is the phone call in which the researcher chats with the mom about morning coffee routines.”

WPO000003_rubric_category_2.ti: C. Describe what the statistically significant difference in means indicates for how long children paid attention to the action in the video.

o.d: Does not accurately describe the identified statistic in relation to the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response restates the identified statistic without directly relating it to the study.

  • The response does not accurately describe what is meant by the identified statistic in relation to the study.

  • The response provides a definition of the identified statistic but does not accurately describe its meaning in relation to the study.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The means is the average of scores in the distribution.”

  • “The mean is 0.63.”

  • “A statistically significant difference means that the mean of the interrupted group was very different from the mean of the non-interrupted group. The magnitude of the difference was big.”

o.d: Accurately describes the identified statistic in relation to the study
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response accurately describes the meaning of the statistically significant difference in means for how long children paid attention to the action in the video as the difference is likely due to the independent variable (the 30-second interrupting phone call).

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The interrupted group did not stare as long as the uninterrupted group, and the results then showed that this was not likely due to chance.”

WPO000003_rubric_category_3.ti: D. Identify one ethical guideline described in the study. Describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.

o.d:
Does not accurately identify one ethical guideline described in the study

AND/OR

Does not correctly describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not identify and/or describe an ethical guideline applied by researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline that researchers should have applied but was not mentioned in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes an ethical guideline not applied by the researchers in the study.

  • The response identifies and describes other features of the study that are not ethical guidelines.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “It’s important for researchers to ensure participants are treated ethically.” [No ethical guideline identified or described]

  • “The researchers should have kept the participant information anonymous.” [Identifies an ethical guideline not described in the study]

  • “The study was approved by an IRB and the researchers debriefed their participants after the study.” [Identifies an ethical guideline described in the study, but no description of how guideline was applied in the study.]

  • “The researchers used surveys that were administered in a standardized way.” [Identifies and describes a feature of the study that is not an ethical guideline]

o.d:
Accurately identifies one ethical guideline described in the study

AND

Accurately describes one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response identifies informed consent and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.

    OR

  • The response identifies confidentiality and describes that the researchers applied it in the study when researchers ensured that the individual participants could not be identified from the data collected.

    OR

  • The response identifies debriefing and describes that researchers informed participants of the true purpose of the study after the study was complete.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study obtained informed consent which is when the participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could back out at any time.”

    OR

  • “Researchers maintained confidentiality when they ensured that the individual participants could not be identified from the data collected.”

    OR

  • “Researchers debriefed participants by telling them what the true purpose of the study was about.”

WPO000003_rubric_category_4.ti: E. Explain the extent to which the research findings may or may not be generalizable using specific and relevant evidence from the study.
WPO000003_rubric_category_4.s: If students assert the study is “partly” generalizable or asserts the study is both generalizable and not generalizable, their evidence must support their assertion by showing ways the study is generalizable and is not generalizable to earn one point.

o.d:
Does not propose a claim regarding the generalizability of the study to a population (general or specific).

OR

Does not use specific and relevant evidence that references participant variables which would impact the generalizability of the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response proposes no claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study.

  • The response proposes a claim regarding the generalizability of the conclusion of the study but makes no reference to a population (general or specific).

  • The response uses evidence that does not apply to the generalizability of the conclusion of the study (e.g., reliability, validity, sample size).

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “The study is generalizable.”

  • “The study is generalizable to the larger population.”

  • “The study used females.” [Does not propose a claim about generalizability].

  • “The study generalizes as it used a within group design which is similar to random assignment.”

o.d: Explains the extent to which the study is generalizable using specific and relevant evidence referencing participant variables from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim about generalizability that references a population (the “larger population” or a population relevant to the study’s participants) to explain the extent of the generalizability of the study.

  • The response proposes that the study is or is not generalizable to the population relevant to the study because of specific and relevant evidence derived from the participant information from the study.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “The study is generalizable to mothers who live in the eastern US.”

  • “The study is generalizable to mothers because the age range of the mothers was pretty large.”

  • “The study is not generalizable to all parents since they only had mothers who were participating.”

  • “Ninety percent of the mothers were White, so it might not be generalizable to non-White mothers.”

WPO000003_rubric_category_5.ti: F. Explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the idea that disruptions can hinder memory.

o.d: Does not accurately explain how the results of the study support or refute the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the idea that disruptions can hinder learning.

  • The response does not accurately explain how at least one of the research findings supports or refutes the idea that disruptions can hinder learning.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Disruptions can hinder learning.”

  • “Disruptions are bad for children’s learning.”

o.d:
Uses the results of the study but does not explain how the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted.

OR

Explains that the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question is supported or refuted but does not use any results from the study.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes that the evidence alone is sufficient to demonstrate the application of the idea that disruptions can hinder learning without additional explanation.

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to explain idea that disruptions can hinder learning. However, the interpretation of the results of the study includes some inaccuracies.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Disruptions can make people miss important stimuli in the environment.” [Explanation without using results]

  • “The research shows that children whose learning was interrupted were less likely to learn a new word.” [Result from the study without further explanation]

  • “The research shows that the number of times the mom’s used the word influenced how well the children learned.” [Evidence includes an inaccurate interpretation.]

o.d: Uses a specific result from the study to explain how the results support or refute the psychological concept or hypothesis presented in the question. The results are accurately interpreted.
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response uses at least one of the research findings to accurately explain the idea that disruptions can hinder learning. The results of the study are accurately interpreted.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “The babies who had their teaching session interrupted were less likely to learn the word than the babies who were not interrupted, meaning that disruptions can make people miss important stimuli in the environment which can affect learning.”

  • “The research shows that interrupting children’s learning can lead to an interruption in encoding, which means that children may not learn as much if they are always being interrupted.”

  • “By showing that the interruptions caused less learning by the children, the researchers were able to demonstrate the importance of attention in getting information into long-term memory.”

  • “The research shows that disruptions may hinder long-term potentiation by not having as many opportunities to repeat the neural chain associated with learning a new word.”

YYM000002_rubric_category_0.ti: A. Propose a specific and defensible claim based in psychological science that responds to the question.
YYM000002_rubric_category_0.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • A claim that meets the criteria can be awarded the points regardless of whether the responses in Parts B and C successfully support the claim.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not propose a claim that is relevant to the question
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response describes the question without making a claim.

  • The response proposes a claim unrelated to the question.

  • The response proposes an oversimplified conclusion or evidence from a provided source.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “People who eat spicy foods tend to live in hot climates.”

  • “Eating spicy foods is related to aggression.”

o.d: Proposes a claim that is relevant to the question
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response proposes a claim that suggests a positive or negative effect on the question.

  • The response proposes a recommendation for the application of the question.

  • The response proposes a specific effect on the question.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “People who eat spicy food tend to have a specific personality type.”

  • “Compared with people who eat spicy food, people who eat non-spicy food are less likely to attribute aggressive intentions to others who engage in ambiguous behaviors.”

YYM000002_rubric_category_1.ti: B. (i) Support your claim using at least one piece of specific and relevant evidence from one of the sources.
YYM000002_rubric_category_1.s:
For Part B and Part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1...”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn this point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. Since citing specific numbers is not required to score the point, slight errors in reporting specific data can still earn the point when the direction of the difference or relationship of the data cited is correct.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not identify nor correctly cite one piece of specific evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim. Any evidence provided is not relevant to the question.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response identifies no evidence.

  • The evidence is not correctly cited.

  • The evidence is nonspecific.

  • The response provides evidence not relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Chinese students are more likely to be aggressive and to eat spicy foods than are students from other cultures.”

  • “Source 1 conducted a correlational study on spicy foods and aggression.”

  • “Reading comprehension tests are not good ways to measure aggression.”

o.d: Uses one piece of correctly cited, specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from one of the provided sources to support the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The evidence is correctly cited and provides specific and accurate evidence relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Source 1 found that participants who ate habanero pepper sauce on a tortilla were more likely to use aggressive words to complete fragments than were those who ate a plain tortilla.”

  • “When ambiguous behaviors are described, aggressive intentions are more likely to be assigned to these behaviors by participants who eat spicy foods than those who eat non-spicy foods (Source 1).”

YYM000002_rubric_category_2.ti: B. (ii) Explain how the evidence from Part B (i) supports your claim using a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology.
YYM000002_rubric_category_2.s:
For Part B and Part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1...”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in B (i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The use of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) is preferred but not required. The application of a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding.

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be evidence. All text before the citation will be considered evidence. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.

  • Concepts used in the sources that are not eligible to be used for the application point are “aggressive,” “gender,” “Likert scale,” “statistical significance,” “mood,” “survey,” “risk-taking,” “mean,” “standard deviation,” “perception,” “personality,” “sweet (taste),” “bitter (taste),” “sour (taste),” “spicy (taste),” irritability,” “attribution,” and “taste.”

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not explain the relationship between the evidence and the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately interpret the evidence.

  • The response identifies evidence without explanation of how it relates to the claim.

  • The response provides opinions with no reference to the sources provided.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Aggression is a significant problem in today’s society.”

  • “College men behaved more aggressively in this study than did college women.”

  • “Participants who ate spicy food had aggression-related thoughts in the experiment.”

o.d: Explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence in supporting the claim, but does not apply a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Participants who ate spicy food were more likely than those who ate non-spicy food to select aggressive words to complete fragments, which confirms Source 1’s hypothesis.”

o.d: Applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding to explain how the evidence supports the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence and applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding correctly.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “This difference may be related to the idea that spicy foods releases substance P, which causes people pain. If people are in pain, then they may behave in ways that are different than normal.”

YYM000002_rubric_category_3.ti: C. (i)  Support your claim using an additional piece of specific and relevant evidence from a different source than the one that was used in Part B (i).
YYM000002_rubric_category_3.s:
For Part B and Part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1...”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • Responses that use correct citation style other than the method prescribed by the question can earn this point for citing the source.

  • “Accurate evidence” refers to the accuracy of the general pattern of the evidence cited. Since citing specific numbers is not required to score the point, slight errors in reporting specific data can still earn the point when the direction of the difference or relationship of the data cited is correct.

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not identify nor correctly cite a different piece of specific evidence from either of the other two provided sources to support the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response identifies no evidence.

  • The evidence is not correctly cited.

  • The evidence is nonspecific.

  • The evidence is from the same source as the one used in Part B.

  • The response provides evidence not relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Source 2 examined the relationship between eating spicy food and risky behavior with a correlational design.”

  • “Source 2 demonstrated that consuming spicy foods heightens extraverted behaviors.”

  • “Extraversion and irritability are related to each other (Source 3).”

  • “Source 3 found that people are more likely to rate strangers as irritable if those strangers report liking sour versus spicy foods.”

o.d: Uses a different piece of correctly cited, specific, accurate, and relevant evidence from either of the other two provided sources to support the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The evidence is correctly cited and provides specific and accurate evidence relevant to the claim.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “Source 2 found that participants who ate bread with spicy chili sauce (M = 61.60, SD = 11.62) were more likely to draw cards from the high reward/high penalties decks than were those who ate bread only (M = 52.85, SD = 8.51).”

  • “Source 3 analyses showed that strangers associated with liking spicy foods were rated as more irritable, on average, than those who were associated with liking sweet foods.”

YYM000002_rubric_category_4.ti: C. (ii) Explain how the evidence from Part C (i) supports your claim using a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology than the one that was used in Part B (ii).
YYM000002_rubric_category_4.s:
For Part B and Part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways:

  • Parenthetical Citation:

    For example: “...(Source 1)”

  • Embedded Citation:

    For example: “According to Source 1...”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Additional Notes:

  • The explanation and application points can be earned even if the response did not earn the point in C (i) due to incorrectly cited and/or nonspecific evidence.

  • The explanation and application points can be earned if the response uses the same source in both Parts B and C, provided that the evidence used in Part B and Part C is different.

  • The use of a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding explicitly identified in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) is preferred but not required. The application of a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is not explicitly included in the AP Psychology Course and Exam Description (2024) must demonstrate psychological knowledge and not popular understanding.

  • The presence of a citation indicates the sentence or phrase is intended to be evidence. All text prior to the citation will be considered evidence. Text after a citation will be considered reasoning, unless accompanied by another citation.

  • Concepts used in the sources that are not eligible to be used for the application point are “aggressive,” “gender,” “Likert scale,” “statistical significance,” “mood,” “survey,” “risk-taking,” “mean,” “standard deviation,” “perception,” “personality,” “sweet (taste),” “bitter (taste),” “sour (taste),” “spicy (taste),” irritability,” “attribution,” and “taste.”

Select a score below.

o.d: Does not meet the criteria for one point.
o.af:
Responses that earn 0 points:

  • The response does not accurately interpret the evidence.

  • The response identifies evidence without explanation of how it relates to the claim.

  • The response provides opinions with no reference to the sources provided.

Examples that earn 0 points:

  • “Data from Chinese college students cannot be generalized or applied to college students from other countries.”

  • “How people approach making risky decisions can be caused by personality (Source 2).”

  • “Source 3 did not find differences in self-reliance ratings.”

o.d: Explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim.
o.af:
Responses that earn 1 point:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence, but does not apply a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding.

  • The response applies the same psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that was used in Part B; however, the response explains the relationship between the evidence and the claim that does not rely on the application.

Examples that earn 1 point:

  • “These studies support the notion that the eating of spicy food can relate to our personality characteristics and associated behaviors.”

  • “According to research by Source 2, people who eat spicy foods are more likely to make risky decisions than those who do not eat spicy foods.”

  • “When people enjoy eating spicy foods, they are likely to be perceived as irritable (Source 3).”

o.d: Applies a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding to explain how the evidence supports the claim. The psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding is different from the one used in Part B (ii).
o.af:
Responses that earn 2 points:

  • The response correctly interprets the evidence and applies a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding that is different from the one used in Part B.

Examples that earn 2 points:

  • “The difference in means supports the researchers’ belief that eating spicy foods can cause temporary changes in people’s risky decision making.”

  • “It may be that by inducing pain or discomfort, spicy foods trigger stress responses that also lead people to make risky decisions.”

  • “One explanation for this finding could be that eating spicy food and being irritable share similar physiological features (e.g., discomfort, perspiration) which are activated by the sympathetic nervous system. As such, we have learned to associate spicy foods and irritability.”
